comment:
Incredible nose. Sweet, kind of "dark sweet". Similar in taste - hot and sweet, even very sweet. And then comes a fury of different tastes - corn, vanilla, honey, fruity syrup and caramel.
  Yeah - lot of sweet :) Bit too much for me, still - this is a great burboun.

Nose - (w/o water) - very hot due to the proof, but light oak, vanilla, sweet cherries, milk caramel. Very hot and sweet. (w/ water) - very similar nose, but with the heat toned down quite a bit. In addition I get a sweet honey and something almost like a sweet chocolate covered pineapple piece.
Taste - (w/o water) - Hit with sweet cherries, vanilla, light oak, sweet milk caramels, slight bitterness like you'd get from overly toasted almond skins in an English toffee. (w/ water) - the water tones it down and I get an extra taste of delicious milk chocolate that has dried cherries in it, wonderful.
Finish - (w/o water) - You get a lingering cinnamon burn that transitions into a slightly bitter taste, like if you bit into a cherry pit or apple seed. There's still hints of sweet vanilla and faint dried cherries. (w/ water) - The water tones down the cinnamon burn as well as the bitterness and I get more of a sweeter vanilla, but the milk chocolate I got in the taste transitions into a darker chocolate with dried cherries.
91/100
this one i opened.very good.sweet,spicy,hint of heat.reminds me of sugar and butter corn with lots of butter.

Only way to describe the nose is "outrageous".  It's on par with the Pappy 20 yr in that regard, and just barely behind on the palate.  It's definitely powerful stuff, so beware on the first sip.  A must own for bourbon fanatics.

128.2 proof... From the nose it's not that apparent that this is a higher proof than the standard Single Barrel offering, and the smell is familiar (meaning, very good). Once you take a sip, however, you realize you're in another tax bracket. Walnuts and peanut brittle smack you immediately, along with cinnamon (the genetically modified kind on steroids). This sharply stings the back of your throat in the most pleasant way possible, and it's warm warm warm going down. An oaky bitterness lingers, along with some nocino notes. Adding a splash of limestone water muted it just slightly, and heightened the vanilla notes a bit. In my view, this isn't just a stronger version of the standard Blanton's, it seemingly tastes like a different animal altogether. This is a muscle car with the engine that sticks out of the hood, the one that gets obnoxiously driven through your neighborhood, rattling the windows of your house as you question its existence, but causes you to daydream what it would be like to be behind the wheel. If Buffalo Trace adds this to the BTAC lineup, I'd understand (even though it probably would be just as hard to find and probably more expensive). Good stuff, worth seeking out. 4/12/17
Think I prefer scotch to bourbon. Strong burn.

NOSE: Rye / Syrup / Caramel

TASTE: Caramel / Vanilla / Oak / Syrup

FINISH: Spectacular

*Sample @ 64.1 ABV

Nose: To my surprise there was little alcohol on the nose. Familiar scents of oak and vanilla. 

Palate: Despite the ABV this came out with a syrupy sweetness to me. Brown sugar, oak, char, dry nuts. It's warm all the way down.

This is fantastic. It's everything you like about the traditional Blanton's amplified to the max. It's big, bold and complex with multiple layers.  It has a surprisingly smooth finish for a barrel proof. I cracked my first bottle with some friends at an annual get together. Everyone loved it. This is one of my favorites and should really be the sixth member of the Antique Collection. The only problem is that it's currently only offered overseas. You can get it online but shipping costs are brutal.

This bourbon gets a 5, but a "soft" 5 (if that makes any sense), in my book.  Blanton's Straight from the Barrel is the forbidden fruit, or at least the far-away fruit, in the Blanton's lineup -- available only overseas and not in the United States.  This bourbon has a dark, almost cloudy, russet, clay-like color.  Dark, sticky fruits, and chewy raisins and craisins, stand out immediately on the nose.  Behind that, there's a clear and harmonious combination of vanilla and caramel.   As a younger whiskey, Blanton's has less oakiness than older bourbons like Elijah Craig Barrel Proof on the nose, although there is a scent reminiscent of pencil shavings some of the time.  Whole peppercorns round out the strong start.  This bourbon drinks well below its proof, but lacks the complexity of the finest barrel-strength releases from other distilleries, or from the older products from Buffalo Trace itself.  Unlike the nose, the palate is heavy on the dry side, with cedar and oak woodiness abounding from the first sip onward.  There's more honey than caramel in this barrel.  The vanilla from the nose carries over well to the palate, but those dark, sticky fruits or dried fruits are nowhere to be found (at least for me).  The smokiness of Blanton's, from the barrel char, is stronger than other barrel-proof bourbons.  The texture is oily, rich, and buttery.  Compared to the nose, I once again get a surprising amount of oak on the swallow, along with cloves and rye spice.  The combination of cinnamon and creaminess is reminiscent of eggnog.  The spice dominates the back-end, which doesn't exhibit the harmony of the first two phases.  At $100, this is one of the most expensive bottles of bourbon I've ever purchased.  However, it's not the best.  With Blanton's, the intangible factors add significantly to the enjoyment.  By that, I mean the beautiful bottle and the fact that this bourbon isn't even available in the U.S., which adds to its cool factor.  But, on taste alone, I'd happily grab a bottle of Elijah Craig Barrel Proof or Four Roses Private Selection for $70-80 (and grab a bottle of Wild Turkey 101 with the savings!).
Echt niet ons ding. Gerookt vlees

Dumped on 7-13-17, barrel no. 892

Nose is sweet tobacco and dark fruit. Notes of brown sugar, leather and peppercorns. Buttery smooth like original Blanton's but with a whole new depth. Smells and drinks well below it's proof. The best of the Blanton's lineup for me.

From the nose to finish, this one is spectacular. Definitely not for the novice. If you have been appreciating the taste of bourbon for awhile, this is a must try. I have always loved the single barrel version as my go to drink. This concoction takes it to another level. The best I’ve tasted so far. Incredible flavor.

HOT HOT. A beautiful kick in the nads
4.65

On the nose a nice, truffle like smell. Unbelievably delicious. Nice thick viscosity, like silk on the tongue. Rich toffee flavor. Nice long finish that tapers off with a red delicious apple flavor. 

5 ⭐️ / $130
The burn is late and long.
My go to when traveling.  Solid!
Close to my definition of a near perfect bourbon.

Nose: Carmel Bomb, dark chocolate, burnt raisins, shortbread, soft leather 
Palate: An Initial Cinnamon rush turning into an explosion of roasted citrus, finishing with a burst of spicy stewed berries 
Finish: Long lasting sweet heat with a good creamy mouthfeel finish. Perfection

It’s good. It’s one of the more drinkable barrel proofs out there. That said, you’re gonna come up to this little guy with expectations that Booker’s (for instance) just doesn’t have to deal with. Particularly: how does stand up to his big brother, Blanton’s standard—one of America’s most highly sought bourbons.

The nose is not as astringent as you’d expect. I get vanilla. The body does have the Blanton’s flavors you’d expect (more vanilla and a nut favor) but they’re overpowered by the heat in a way that big brother isn’t. This spiciness comes to me via black pepper. What’s interesting is that on the finish, the heat fades quickly, leaving behind a nutty favor, with a bit of lemon.

With an ice cube added, I can get the nut flavor on the nose and lemon on the body. Heat turns down quite a bit and finish gets even sweeter. I think I prefer this one on the rocks, and to date, Blanton’s Gold is the best of the Blanton’s gang.

Wow. I love Blantons and it is my regular drinking whiskey but this is next level. Take all of the fantastic flavors of regular Blantons and multiply them. Wrong but oh so smooth. Speechless. If I could give this higher then 5 I would. It’s pricey but it’s also >130 proof and straight from the barrel.
This one is very good !!! Strong and smooth. Grab a sip of you have the chance!!!!

130.6
Bottled 11-1-16

Nose- Stunning nose. Think regular Blanton’s, but on steroids. Lots of orange citrus, dried fruits, and caramel. It smells like a wether’s original candy. Alcohol is slightly noticeable, but at 130 proof very muted. 
Palate-This is one HOT bourbon. It is very thick and chewy, but I couldn’t quite pick out notes due to the heat. I added 4 drops of water and this opened up beautifully. Water brought out the sweetness. Honey, butterscotch, vanilla, and that wonderful black pepper. Oak and pepper on the back end of the palate. 
Finish-The heat comes back on the back end, but in an amazing way. The finish is dry, but very long. It allows you to think about your sip before diving back in for more. I get lots of the rye spice and dry fruit. 
Conclusion-I love barrel proof bourbons and admittedly I’m a huge fan of Blanton’s, but this takes my love affair to another level. This is my favorite pour that I’ve ever had. SFTB could easily be the sixth offering in the BTAC

Nose- Sweat tea and green apple
Body- Rich with brown sugar and creamy caramel. Fruit notes are there too with rich plum giving way to the dry citrus. 
Finish- Spicy but fairly short finish. In 
fact, I find the finish to be a bit shorter than the gold rendition. You definitely feel the high proof here.

I love the beginning of this dram. There is a rich mouthfeel that really coats your tongue with sweet and fruity notes. However, at this abv (127.3) the finish is a bit challenging. I look forward to experimenting with a bit of water or ice. Very good overall but the gold wins out for me for a neat pour. 

First enjoyed this in a blind taste test where I destroyed Milliardo and Freeeeeeeedom! Haha!
Brown sugar, toffee, figs, rich full. One of if not best bourbons I’ve ever had.  Just a drop or two of water but never tastes harsh

This bourbon was dumped on 11-4-16 from barrel No. 585. It was stored in Warehouse H on Rick No. 25. The registered Bottle No. is 67, and comes in at 131.8 proof.

Big bold, rich bourbon that’s packing some heat. Has a nice amount of oak along with vanilla, light honey, butterscotch, and plump juicy raisins. Did I mention that it packs a lot of heat? A must buy if you're able to find it!

Nose: citrus, oak, pepper, vanilla. Blanton’s through and through. The palate packs every bit of punch you’d expect from a barrel proof high-rye mash bill. Citrus, oak, and pepper continue, and are joined by a honeyed sweetness that can be found amongst the high proof heat. Strong pepper and oak finish that sticks around just long enough, with a pleasant warmth. The heat doesn’t wrap your tongue the way a Stagg does, but is enjoyable nonetheless. If barrel proof bourbon is your thing, this is highly approachable even without a few drops of water, but it does respond well to a small amount and I would still suggest adding this to bring out the fruity notes. A substantial improvement on Blanton’s single barrel and a top choice in its own right.
perfect about of Carmel sweetness and heat!
Very hot and spicy, but delicious with fruit undertones.

I don’t get it.  Why would this be limited to outside the US only?  Makes no sense...this can be right up there with Elijah Craig single barrel cask strength or Four Roses LESB releases.   Amazing aroma of sweet caramel, oranges, and some oak.  Taste doesn’t pull any punches...thick viscous, oranges and brown sugar.  Some heat...with a lingering long orange citrus finish.  Till today, I think the best bourbon I’ve had was the Four Roses 2016 LESB, but this falls close second.  Thanks @Dreaming-of-Islay for the pour!
Blanton's the way it's meant to be.
Everything I love about Blanton’s with a wonderful added punch.  Amazing.
one of the best bourbons period!

Even better than gold (Blanton’s gold). Very smooth - definitely need a wee bit of branch water 129.6 proof.  Worth sending to the UK for.  Too bad it’s produced in the States yet we’re not worthy (do I sound bitter😢?)

130.3 proof / 65.15% alc
Very Smooth for the proof
Light Tobacco / Barrel spice
Marmalade / Creme brûlée / Ripened red fruits
Unripened almond bitters
Gets better the longer it dilutes and breathes.

One of the best bourbons I’ve ever had, and the perfect choice for a winter’s night - candy sweetness and spice on the nose, marzipan, almond toffee and honey in the taste, and a hint of cinnamon on the finish.

N:Quite sweet and fruity. Slight oak barrel and leathery on the finish. Much like regular Blantons but highly elevated. 
P: very similar to the nose. Tons of berry and stone fruit shine through initially. A little bit of vanilla sneaks in before the heat really ramps up. This really lets you know it’s a barrel proof bourbon and tingles your tongue. This is quite enjoyable but for those who don’t like high proofers I would suggest holding off until you come to enjoy these types of bourbon. Its quite good but would turn off most initially in my opinion.

Considered to be one of the world's best Bourbons. This bottle was “dumped” on the 13th February 2017 from barrel number 47. Proof = Cask.

Nose – Carmel - Powerful, marked by honey, wooded vanilla, spices, tobacco and fudge.
Taste – Oak & Vanilla - Full, rich and creamy marked by citrus, butter, spice, honey, and heavy oak. Ginger Ale or Cola are the best mixers.
Finish - Long, with peaches and citrus, leading to a soft buttery chocolate aftertaste.

(credit to published reviews - on which I built mine)

Nose is pure caramel apple. Tasting neat is a touch heavy on the palate, particularly from the alcohol. Opens up beautifully with a single ice cube or a few drops of water. Stronger barrel proof makes it a bit nicer than “stock” Blanton’s to me.
Simply fantastic. Finish is exceptionally smooth for a bourbon of this proof. Easily a top 5 for me.
full of flavor. cinnamon and spice. long finish

Opened my bottle as CBJ swept TB 4-0 in playoffs. 🙌
Nose: sweet, subtle spice, minimal ethanol for this proof
Palate: like Blantons *5, sweet, oak, spice all amped up
Finish: there’s the heat right up front, very long finish with sweetness at the end

Abv% 131
Nose- as my other posts say it is very similar to the Blantons regular with a bit more alcohol burn. Very nice and warm. A very strong Vanilla smell. 
Pallet- reminds of most other barrel proof drinks has that strong alcohol burn at first. Very good pallet after the drink. Reminds me of another fav barrel proof Stagg Jr. I managed to procure a bottle of this and it will be cherished to the last drop with fellow enthusiast don’t think normies would understand its greatness.
Same blantons flavor, but strong. Makes me want a stogie. Somewhat oily, and damn good.
127.5 proof. Strong alcohol finish but no burn. Delicious
very rich and sweet with some complexity and a good finish. much better than the standard expression.  my sample was from barrel 48 and was 128.2 proof.

This is some delicious stuff. Sweet and spicy with notes of caramel, baking spices, biscuits, toffee, dried fruits, clove, and pepper. Evaporates in my mouth. At cask strength, you will first get alcohol on the nose but with time, you’ll get many of the great flavors on the nose
In my top two.  Not for the weak. As advertised.
Amazing complexity, fresh wood covered with vanilla and caramel with a sight spicy backdrop.
has the same nose and taste as blantons but I had the highest proof I have seen at 138.5 and it was hot! needed a couple drops of water but absolutely delicious for such of a high proof
like how Blanton's should be bottled.
Incredible pour. Worth the price. Buy yourself a bottle

Da Wife picked dis up in Aruba cuz you can’t git it anywhere up in tha States. I gots a straight-up boner fo' Blanton’s but dis be a lil' bit bangin' fo' mah taste. I feel tha bangin' is detractin fo' tha familiar Blanton’s signature taste.
cinnamon, small hint of cherry, vanilla, honey.
Bold up front, butterscotch and vanilla. Finishes HOT. Should be a BTAC, it’s that good. Comparable to a GTS or WLW
Drinks below the proof.  A MUST experience for all bourbon lovers
Great bourbon, smooth for the proof.  It’s Blanton’s on steroids, exactly what you would expect.  Do get a bit of a tea note on nose and palate.  WTF don’t they sell this in the US?
Spicy cherry on the nose with an oaky body and earl grey tea on the finish. 6-18-18 63.8%
Smooth, vanilla bomb with strong proof

Talk about a rare find, and an incredible bourbon. If you think the original Blanton's was good, then this stuff will knock you on your a$$. 

The nose has strong notes of butter, pears, raspberry jam and pecans.

The taste is even better with flavors of honey, molasses cookies, light cinnamon, oil and butter. 

Very, VERY good. This is a treat and an experience.
Spicy and tingly. I prefer the Gold for sure.

Heard some great things about this so had to try it. I mean c'mon it's cask strength Blanton's. Strong caramel, cinnamon, and everything nice on the nose. Spicy to taste and lots of burn but then goes down really smooth. Will definitely keep this stocked in the collection.

Nose: fruit bomb! With a little caramel coming through as well
Palate: so rich and powerful. So much fruit and everything else. Honestly can barely handle this one which is at 130 proof. Very good but just so much
Finish: very long finish of oak and caramel

A VERY generous gift from dthom.  Wow is this good!  Everything I like about Blanton's but turned up to 11.

Nose: Granny smith apple big time!  Caramelized brown sugars, vanilla, quite a bit of oak, cinnamon, and oatmeal.  Smells like apple cobbler.

Flavor: Poached apples, dark sugars, crème brulee, heavy cereal oatmeal notes, baking spices.  Even more apple cobbler.  VERY buttery and delicious.

Finish: Medium length, some rye spice, intense dried tart apples, calvados, and toasted nuts.

Wow is this good!  I'm blown away.  Everything I love about Blantons here but just more of everything.
Decent kick while still remaining balanced. I dig it

Nose consists of marmalade, pistachios, and almond butter overriding a faint bread character (almost like sponge cake) before giving way to a wallop of black pepper (fruity, as it smells before the peppercorns are cracked). Palate has punchy rye spice, with citrus and vanilla wafers coming forward. Finish is medium, with a definite proof heat that dries back into the pepper and faint char.
Best to date. So smooth and Carmelly for a 126 proof.  Bought in Barcelona.

Heard some great things about this so had to try it. I mean c'mon it's cask strength Blanton's. Strong caramel, cinnamon, and everything nice on the nose. Spicy to taste and lots of burn but then goes down really smooth. Will definitely keep this stocked in the collection.

Neat.  Color notably darker than basic Blanton’s.  Nose is Blanton’s turned way up as expected.  Caramel, lots of baking space, honey, powdered sugar, deep dark cherry.  Cherry pastry even.

Really thick texture.  All sugar up front.  Blast of chocolate (I was not expecting) on the first sip, chased by tons of vanilla and a hint of spice.  Legs are mostly vanilla on first sip.  Sugar upfront still in the second hit but got some delightful cherry too.  Chocolate, vanilla, pastry swirl on the taste still.

Okay, this is a really good Barrel.  The nose was just Blanton’s turned up but the taste is something totally different and special.

Went back to basic Blanton’s immediately after.  It’s thin and almost off putting in the head to head comparison.  

Phew, no regrets getting this SFTB!

Tried thanks to Jon swapping samples. At 130 proof you definitely get the heat but also a bit of the sweetness you are use to from Blanton’s single barrel. Definitely need to add a bottle to the collection (ideally around $135 etc)
Little hot, but really good! Lot of barrel notes.

A very unique note here:  baked bread + skunky beer.  Love it, vanilla caramel on the palate and a very enjoyable finish.  Drinks well below the proof.  I wouldn't search out Blanton's regular after having this.

Nose- Honey, Caramel, cinnamon sugar, rye spices, citrus, and a unique baked bread smell. With water added a biscuity note starts to come out.

Palate- Spice coats the mouth, followed by a wave of caramel and bright citrus. Adding water doesn’t change the palate much- but does take away some spice and replace it with creamy vanilla notes. 

Finish- Long, drying finish with notes of toasted oak and honey

Fantastic nose for such a high proof bourbon. The palate is good- but didn’t amaze me and is very hot. Not as impressed with this one as I thought I would be. A bit one dimensional, albeit enjoyable.

Dumped on 3/28/19 Barrel # 372 Proof 125.6

AMAZING! Butter and barrel on the nose with hints of brown sugar. On the palate it is incredibly viscous, like eating buttery corn. Notes of barrel and some spice leads to a strong finish that seems to keep going. One of the best pours I’ve ever had!
Coconut, sweet, with smooth finish. Hot whiskey first and evens out. Delicious!!
Barrel 1323 Warehouse H. Bottling date: 08/28/2018. Honey, vanilla, roast nuts, spice, floral notes. Though it is good, I look for more richness. Not my style
Sweet, black cherry, lots of flavor!

Unbelievable! I’ve been looking for this one for a long time and it does not disappoint. Beautiful complex nose, lots of cherry pralines and molasses. Lovely oily texture and probably the longest aftertaste I have experienced. Amazing stuff!

This is the first time I have given anything a 5.  I thought this might be a bunch of hype but wow!  High proof but not overwhelming and lots of flavor comes through!   A must have if you can find one
Very good.  Lots of cherry and oak.   Best blantons.

N: strong alcohol presence straight away. Gives way to deep rich caramel mixed with overload of baking spices
P: first sip is just straight alcohol. Leads up to apples and baking spices. Very warming.
F: Very long finish. Spiced, baked apples.
Rick 52, dumped on 8-27-18. 131.8 proof. Thanks Andy! All of the great Blanton’s flavors on steroids. Better than my first (and only other) SFTB taste.

N: Fresh cut grass, vanilla, caramel
P: caramel, cinnamon, cherry, oily
F: Oak, char, and long

Good golly. This is fiery and complex and then vanishes with a smooth finish that begs for the next sip. We’ll done, produce a product that allows the end user the ability to define the tasting experience. Straight, rocks, dab of distilled water, choose your adventure. This is solid, everything you want from a bourbon but with an adorable snarl.

N - leather, oak, bit of pepper, light and floral 

P - rich and oily, slight medicinal note with a cherry trail on the end

F - sweet and smooth, everything you’d wish for in Blantons 

Not a fan of the original but this is something special

Nose- smooth - oak -pepper - leather - warmth. 
Finish - leather - oil - cinnamon- perfect heat and finish - one of the best

Nose- Cherries, oak, slight rye. 
Palate- Intense cherry, chocolate, baking spice, cola, carbonated feel
Finish- baking spice, cinnamon into into apple

After going through several bottles of regular Blanton’s, I have been envious of those able to get their hands on the Straight From The Barrel version, which is not sold within the U.S. But after tracking one down online, I’m finally able to see what a barrel proofed version of this infamous bourbon is like. This one is bottled at 129.6 proof.

The nose has an explosion of cooked red apples, cotton candy sweetness, baking spices, oak,  and freshly baked bread. 

The palate is sweet and oily with fresh apples,  leather, oak, sweet caramel, baking spices, corn and brown sugar. It’s also fairly drying on the palate, which is common with higher proof bourbons.

The finish tingles down your jawline, and the top of the throat for a long finish with lingering vanilla, fruit and spices.

Man, this is so delicious. Even though it’s not a fair comparison to regular old Blanton’s at a modest 93 proof, I had to compare. And the Straight From The Barrel is just insanely better, to be expected. If you have the opportunity to get ahold of one of these under $200, go for it!
Best mouthfeel I’ve had on a bourbon. Felt and tasted buttery. Great barrel presence and heat followed by caramel and spices. Very long finish as well. Landed a great bottle!
Toasted sweet vanilla nose and very spicy oak with fruits when water added.  Might need more water.  Bottom of the glass is heavy in raisins!!

you can tell immediately this isn’t your regular blanton’s. the nose is immediately full of proof & takes a bit to get through to the flavor notes. the palette has no problem with flavor.  tasty & classic bourbon!
